meta.label: Metadata
meta.help: Metadata fields automatically maintained by OpenClaw to record write/version history for this config file. Keep these values system-managed and avoid manual edits unless debugging migration history.

meta.lastTouchedVersion.label: Config Last Touched Version
meta.lastTouchedVersion.help: Auto-set when OpenClaw writes the config.

meta.lastTouchedAt.label: Config Last Touched At
meta.lastTouchedAt.help: ISO timestamp of the last config write (auto-set).

env.label: Environment
env.help: Environment import and override settings used to supply runtime variables to the gateway process. Use this section to control shell-env loading and explicit variable injection behavior.

env.shellEnv.label: Shell Environment Import
env.shellEnv.help: Shell environment import controls for loading variables from your login shell during startup. Keep this enabled when you depend on profile-defined secrets or PATH customizations.

env.shellEnv.enabled.label: Shell Environment Import Enabled
env.shellEnv.enabled.help: Enables loading environment variables from the user shell profile during startup initialization. Keep enabled for developer machines, or disable in locked-down service environments with explicit env management.

env.shellEnv.timeoutMs.label: Shell Environment Import Timeout (ms)
env.shellEnv.timeoutMs.help: Maximum time in milliseconds allowed for shell environment resolution before fallback behavior applies. Use tighter timeouts for faster startup, or increase when shell initialization is heavy.

env.vars.label: Environment Variable Overrides
env.vars.help: Explicit key/value environment variable overrides merged into runtime process environment for OpenClaw. Use this for deterministic env configuration instead of relying only on shell profile side effects.

wizard.label: Setup Wizard State
wizard.help: Setup wizard state tracking fields that record the most recent guided onboarding run details. Keep these fields for observability and troubleshooting of setup flows across upgrades.

wizard.lastRunAt.label: Wizard Last Run Timestamp
wizard.lastRunAt.help: ISO timestamp for when the setup wizard most recently completed on this host. Use this to confirm onboarding recency during support and operational audits.

wizard.lastRunVersion.label: Wizard Last Run Version
wizard.lastRunVersion.help: OpenClaw version recorded at the time of the most recent wizard run on this config. Use this when diagnosing behavior differences across version-to-version onboarding changes.

wizard.lastRunCommit.label: Wizard Last Run Commit
wizard.lastRunCommit.help: Source commit identifier recorded for the last wizard execution in development builds. Use this to correlate onboarding behavior with exact source state during debugging.

wizard.lastRunCommand.label: Wizard Last Run Command
wizard.lastRunCommand.help: Command invocation recorded for the latest wizard run to preserve execution context. Use this to reproduce onboarding steps when verifying setup regressions.

wizard.lastRunMode.label: Wizard Last Run Mode
wizard.lastRunMode.help: Wizard execution mode recorded as "local" or "remote" for the most recent onboarding flow. Use this to understand whether setup targeted direct local runtime or remote gateway topology.

diagnostics.label: Diagnostics
diagnostics.help: Diagnostics controls for targeted tracing, telemetry export, and cache inspection during debugging. Keep baseline diagnostics minimal in production and enable deeper signals only when investigating issues.

diagnostics.otel.label: OpenTelemetry
diagnostics.otel.help: OpenTelemetry export settings for traces, metrics, and logs emitted by gateway components. Use this when integrating with centralized observability backends and distributed tracing pipelines.

diagnostics.cacheTrace.label: Cache Trace
diagnostics.cacheTrace.help: Cache-trace logging settings for observing cache decisions and payload context in embedded runs. Enable this temporarily for debugging and disable afterward to reduce sensitive log footprint.

logging.label: Logging
logging.help: Logging behavior controls for severity, output destinations, formatting, and sensitive-data redaction. Keep levels and redaction strict enough for production while preserving useful diagnostics.

logging.level.label: Log Level
logging.level.help: Primary log level threshold for runtime logger output: "silent", "fatal", "error", "warn", "info", "debug", or "trace". Keep "info" or "warn" for production, and use debug/trace only during investigation.

logging.file.label: Log File Path
logging.file.help: Optional file path for persisted log output in addition to or instead of console logging. Use a managed writable path and align retention/rotation with your operational policy.

logging.consoleLevel.label: Console Log Level
logging.consoleLevel.help: Console-specific log threshold: "silent", "fatal", "error", "warn", "info", "debug", or "trace" for terminal output control. Use this to keep local console quieter while retaining richer file logging if needed.

logging.consoleStyle.label: Console Log Style
logging.consoleStyle.help: Console output format style: "pretty", "compact", or "json" based on operator and ingestion needs. Use json for machine parsing pipelines and pretty/compact for human-first terminal workflows.

logging.redactSensitive.label: Sensitive Data Redaction Mode
logging.redactSensitive.help: Sensitive redaction mode: "off" disables built-in masking, while "tools" redacts sensitive tool/config payload fields. Keep "tools" in shared logs unless you have isolated secure log sinks.

logging.redactPatterns.label: Custom Redaction Patterns
logging.redactPatterns.help: Additional custom redact regex patterns applied to log output before emission/storage. Use this to mask org-specific tokens and identifiers not covered by built-in redaction rules.

update.label: Updates
update.help: Update-channel and startup-check behavior for keeping OpenClaw runtime versions current. Use conservative channels in production and more experimental channels only in controlled environments.

update.channel.label: Update Channel
update.channel.help: Update channel for git + npm installs ("stable", "beta", or "dev").

update.checkOnStart.label: Update Check on Start
update.checkOnStart.help: Check for npm updates when the gateway starts (default: true).

update.auto.enabled.label: Auto Update Enabled
update.auto.enabled.help: Enable background auto-update for package installs (default: false).

update.auto.stableDelayHours.label: Auto Update Stable Delay (hours)
update.auto.stableDelayHours.help: Minimum delay before stable-channel auto-apply starts (default: 6).

update.auto.stableJitterHours.label: Auto Update Stable Jitter (hours)
update.auto.stableJitterHours.help: Extra stable-channel rollout spread window in hours (default: 12).

update.auto.betaCheckIntervalHours.label: Auto Update Beta Check Interval (hours)
update.auto.betaCheckIntervalHours.help: How often beta-channel checks run in hours (default: 1).

diagnostics.enabled.label: Diagnostics Enabled
diagnostics.enabled.help: Master toggle for diagnostics instrumentation output in logs and telemetry wiring paths. Keep enabled for normal observability, and disable only in tightly constrained environments.

diagnostics.flags.label: Diagnostics Flags
diagnostics.flags.help: Enable targeted diagnostics logs by flag (e.g. ["telegram.http"]). Supports wildcards like "telegram.*" or "*".

diagnostics.otel.enabled.label: OpenTelemetry Enabled
diagnostics.otel.enabled.help: Enables OpenTelemetry export pipeline for traces, metrics, and logs based on configured endpoint/protocol settings. Keep disabled unless your collector endpoint and auth are fully configured.

diagnostics.otel.endpoint.label: OpenTelemetry Endpoint
diagnostics.otel.endpoint.help: Collector endpoint URL used for OpenTelemetry export transport, including scheme and port. Use a reachable, trusted collector endpoint and monitor ingestion errors after rollout.

diagnostics.otel.protocol.label: OpenTelemetry Protocol
diagnostics.otel.protocol.help: OTel transport protocol for telemetry export: "http/protobuf" or "grpc" depending on collector support. Use the protocol your observability backend expects to avoid dropped telemetry payloads.

diagnostics.otel.headers.label: OpenTelemetry Headers
diagnostics.otel.headers.help: Additional HTTP/gRPC metadata headers sent with OpenTelemetry export requests, often used for tenant auth or routing. Keep secrets in env-backed values and avoid unnecessary header sprawl.

diagnostics.otel.serviceName.label: OpenTelemetry Service Name
diagnostics.otel.serviceName.help: Service name reported in telemetry resource attributes to identify this gateway instance in observability backends. Use stable names so dashboards and alerts remain consistent over deployments.

diagnostics.otel.traces.label: OpenTelemetry Traces Enabled
diagnostics.otel.traces.help: Enable trace signal export to the configured OpenTelemetry collector endpoint. Keep enabled when latency/debug tracing is needed, and disable if you only want metrics/logs.

diagnostics.otel.metrics.label: OpenTelemetry Metrics Enabled
diagnostics.otel.metrics.help: Enable metrics signal export to the configured OpenTelemetry collector endpoint. Keep enabled for runtime health dashboards, and disable only if metric volume must be minimized.

diagnostics.otel.logs.label: OpenTelemetry Logs Enabled
diagnostics.otel.logs.help: Enable log signal export through OpenTelemetry in addition to local logging sinks. Use this when centralized log correlation is required across services and agents.

diagnostics.otel.sampleRate.label: OpenTelemetry Trace Sample Rate
diagnostics.otel.sampleRate.help: Trace sampling rate (0-1) controlling how much trace traffic is exported to observability backends. Lower rates reduce overhead/cost, while higher rates improve debugging fidelity.

diagnostics.otel.flushIntervalMs.label: OpenTelemetry Flush Interval (ms)
diagnostics.otel.flushIntervalMs.help: Interval in milliseconds for periodic telemetry flush from buffers to the collector. Increase to reduce export chatter, or lower for faster visibility during active incident response.

diagnostics.cacheTrace.enabled.label: Cache Trace Enabled
diagnostics.cacheTrace.enabled.help: Log cache trace snapshots for embedded agent runs (default: false).

diagnostics.cacheTrace.filePath.label: Cache Trace File Path
diagnostics.cacheTrace.filePath.help: JSONL output path for cache trace logs (default: $OPENCLAW_STATE_DIR/logs/cache-trace.jsonl).

diagnostics.cacheTrace.includeMessages.label: Cache Trace Include Messages
diagnostics.cacheTrace.includeMessages.help: Include full message payloads in trace output (default: true).

diagnostics.cacheTrace.includePrompt.label: Cache Trace Include Prompt
diagnostics.cacheTrace.includePrompt.help: Include prompt text in trace output (default: true).

diagnostics.cacheTrace.includeSystem.label: Cache Trace Include System
diagnostics.cacheTrace.includeSystem.help: Include system prompt in trace output (default: true).

agents.list.*.identity.avatar.label: Identity Avatar
agents.list.*.identity.avatar.help: Agent avatar (workspace-relative path, http(s) URL, or data URI).

agents.list.*.skills.label: Agent Skill Filter
agents.list.*.skills.help: Optional allowlist of skills for this agent (omit = all skills; empty = no skills).

agents.label: Agents
agents.help: Agent runtime configuration root covering defaults and explicit agent entries used for routing and execution context. Keep this section explicit so model/tool behavior stays predictable across multi-agent workflows.

agents.defaults.label: Agent Defaults
agents.defaults.help: Shared default settings inherited by agents unless overridden per entry in agents.list. Use defaults to enforce consistent baseline behavior and reduce duplicated per-agent configuration.

agents.list.label: Agent List
agents.list.help: Explicit list of configured agents with IDs and optional overrides for model, tools, identity, and workspace. Keep IDs stable over time so bindings, approvals, and session routing remain deterministic.

gateway.label: Gateway
gateway.help: Gateway runtime surface for bind mode, auth, control UI, remote transport, and operational safety controls. Keep conservative defaults unless you intentionally expose the gateway beyond trusted local interfaces.

gateway.port.label: Gateway Port
gateway.port.help: TCP port used by the gateway listener for API, control UI, and channel-facing ingress paths. Use a dedicated port and avoid collisions with reverse proxies or local developer services.

gateway.mode.label: Gateway Mode
gateway.mode.help: Gateway operation mode: "local" runs channels and agent runtime on this host, while "remote" connects through remote transport. Keep "local" unless you intentionally run a split remote gateway topology.

gateway.bind.label: Gateway Bind Mode
gateway.bind.help: Network bind profile: "auto", "lan", "loopback", "custom", or "tailnet" to control interface exposure. Keep "loopback" or "auto" for safest local operation unless external clients must connect.

gateway.customBindHost.label: Gateway Custom Bind Host
gateway.customBindHost.help: Explicit bind host/IP used when gateway.bind is set to custom for manual interface targeting. Use a precise address and avoid wildcard binds unless external exposure is required.

gateway.controlUi.label: Control UI
gateway.controlUi.help: Control UI hosting settings including enablement, pathing, and browser-origin/auth hardening behavior. Keep UI exposure minimal and pair with strong auth controls before internet-facing deployments.

gateway.controlUi.enabled.label: Control UI Enabled
gateway.controlUi.enabled.help: Enables serving the gateway Control UI from the gateway HTTP process when true. Keep enabled for local administration, and disable when an external control surface replaces it.

gateway.auth.label: Gateway Auth
gateway.auth.help: Authentication policy for gateway HTTP/WebSocket access including mode, credentials, trusted-proxy behavior, and rate limiting. Keep auth enabled for every non-loopback deployment.

gateway.auth.mode.label: Gateway Auth Mode
gateway.auth.mode.help: Gateway auth mode: "none", "token", "password", or "trusted-proxy" depending on your edge architecture. Use token/password for direct exposure, and trusted-proxy only behind hardened identity-aware proxies.

gateway.auth.allowTailscale.label: Gateway Auth Allow Tailscale Identity
gateway.auth.allowTailscale.help: Allows trusted Tailscale identity paths to satisfy gateway auth checks when configured. Use this only when your tailnet identity posture is strong and operator workflows depend on it.

gateway.auth.rateLimit.label: Gateway Auth Rate Limit
gateway.auth.rateLimit.help: Login/auth attempt throttling controls to reduce credential brute-force risk at the gateway boundary. Keep enabled in exposed environments and tune thresholds to your traffic baseline.

gateway.auth.trustedProxy.label: Gateway Trusted Proxy Auth
gateway.auth.trustedProxy.help: Trusted-proxy auth header mapping for upstream identity providers that inject user claims. Use only with known proxy CIDRs and strict header allowlists to prevent spoofed identity headers.

gateway.trustedProxies.label: Gateway Trusted Proxy CIDRs
gateway.trustedProxies.help: CIDR/IP allowlist of upstream proxies permitted to provide forwarded client identity headers. Keep this list narrow so untrusted hops cannot impersonate users.

gateway.allowRealIpFallback.label: Gateway Allow x-real-ip Fallback
gateway.allowRealIpFallback.help: Enables x-real-ip fallback when x-forwarded-for is missing in proxy scenarios. Keep disabled unless your ingress stack requires this compatibility behavior.

gateway.tools.label: Gateway Tool Exposure Policy
gateway.tools.help: Gateway-level tool exposure allow/deny policy that can restrict runtime tool availability independent of agent/tool profiles. Use this for coarse emergency controls and production hardening.

gateway.tools.allow.label: Gateway Tool Allowlist
gateway.tools.allow.help: Explicit gateway-level tool allowlist when you want a narrow set of tools available at runtime. Use this for locked-down environments where tool scope must be tightly controlled.

gateway.tools.deny.label: Gateway Tool Denylist
gateway.tools.deny.help: Explicit gateway-level tool denylist to block risky tools even if lower-level policies allow them. Use deny rules for emergency response and defense-in-depth hardening.

gateway.channelHealthCheckMinutes.label: Gateway Channel Health Check Interval (min)
gateway.channelHealthCheckMinutes.help: Interval in minutes for automatic channel health probing and status updates. Use lower intervals for faster detection, or higher intervals to reduce periodic probe noise.

gateway.tailscale.label: Gateway Tailscale
gateway.tailscale.help: Tailscale integration settings for Serve/Funnel exposure and lifecycle handling on gateway start/exit. Keep off unless your deployment intentionally relies on Tailscale ingress.

gateway.tailscale.mode.label: Gateway Tailscale Mode
gateway.tailscale.mode.help: Tailscale publish mode: "off", "serve", or "funnel" for private or public exposure paths. Use "serve" for tailnet-only access and "funnel" only when public internet reachability is required.

gateway.tailscale.resetOnExit.label: Gateway Tailscale Reset on Exit
gateway.tailscale.resetOnExit.help: Resets Tailscale Serve/Funnel state on gateway exit to avoid stale published routes after shutdown. Keep enabled unless another controller manages publish lifecycle outside the gateway.

gateway.remote.label: Remote Gateway
gateway.remote.help: Remote gateway connection settings for direct or SSH transport when this instance proxies to another runtime host. Use remote mode only when split-host operation is intentionally configured.

gateway.remote.transport.label: Remote Gateway Transport
gateway.remote.transport.help: Remote connection transport: "direct" uses configured URL connectivity, while "ssh" tunnels through SSH. Use SSH when you need encrypted tunnel semantics without exposing remote ports.

gateway.reload.label: Config Reload
gateway.reload.help: Live config-reload policy for how edits are applied and when full restarts are triggered. Keep hybrid behavior for safest operational updates unless debugging reload internals.

gateway.tls.label: Gateway TLS
gateway.tls.help: TLS certificate and key settings for terminating HTTPS directly in the gateway process. Use explicit certificates in production and avoid plaintext exposure on untrusted networks.

gateway.tls.enabled.label: Gateway TLS Enabled
gateway.tls.enabled.help: Enables TLS termination at the gateway listener so clients connect over HTTPS/WSS directly. Keep enabled for direct internet exposure or any untrusted network boundary.

gateway.tls.autoGenerate.label: Gateway TLS Auto-Generate Cert
gateway.tls.autoGenerate.help: Auto-generates a local TLS certificate/key pair when explicit files are not configured. Use only for local/dev setups and replace with real certificates for production traffic.

gateway.tls.certPath.label: Gateway TLS Certificate Path
gateway.tls.certPath.help: Filesystem path to the TLS certificate file used by the gateway when TLS is enabled. Use managed certificate paths and keep renewal automation aligned with this location.

gateway.tls.keyPath.label: Gateway TLS Key Path
gateway.tls.keyPath.help: Filesystem path to the TLS private key file used by the gateway when TLS is enabled. Keep this key file permission-restricted and rotate per your security policy.

gateway.tls.caPath.label: Gateway TLS CA Path
gateway.tls.caPath.help: Optional CA bundle path for client verification or custom trust-chain requirements at the gateway edge. Use this when private PKI or custom certificate chains are part of deployment.

gateway.http.label: Gateway HTTP API
gateway.http.help: Gateway HTTP API configuration grouping endpoint toggles and transport-facing API exposure controls. Keep only required endpoints enabled to reduce attack surface.

gateway.http.endpoints.label: Gateway HTTP Endpoints
gateway.http.endpoints.help: HTTP endpoint feature toggles under the gateway API surface for compatibility routes and optional integrations. Enable endpoints intentionally and monitor access patterns after rollout.

gateway.remote.url.label: Remote Gateway URL
gateway.remote.url.help: Remote Gateway WebSocket URL (ws:// or wss://).

gateway.remote.sshTarget.label: Remote Gateway SSH Target
gateway.remote.sshTarget.help: Remote gateway over SSH (tunnels the gateway port to localhost). Format: user@host or user@host:port.

gateway.remote.sshIdentity.label: Remote Gateway SSH Identity
gateway.remote.sshIdentity.help: Optional SSH identity file path (passed to ssh -i).

gateway.remote.token.label: Remote Gateway Token
gateway.remote.token.help: Bearer token used to authenticate this client to a remote gateway in token-auth deployments. Store via secret/env substitution and rotate alongside remote gateway auth changes.

gateway.remote.password.label: Remote Gateway Password
gateway.remote.password.help: Password credential used for remote gateway authentication when password mode is enabled. Keep this secret managed externally and avoid plaintext values in committed config.

gateway.remote.tlsFingerprint.label: Remote Gateway TLS Fingerprint
gateway.remote.tlsFingerprint.help: Expected sha256 TLS fingerprint for the remote gateway (pin to avoid MITM).

gateway.auth.token.label: Gateway Token
gateway.auth.token.help: Required by default for gateway access (unless using Tailscale Serve identity); required for non-loopback binds.

browser.label: Browser
browser.help: Browser runtime controls for local or remote CDP attachment, profile routing, and screenshot/snapshot behavior. Keep defaults unless your automation workflow requires custom browser transport settings.

browser.enabled.label: Browser Enabled
browser.enabled.help: Enables browser capability wiring in the gateway so browser tools and CDP-driven workflows can run. Disable when browser automation is not needed to reduce surface area and startup work.

browser.cdpUrl.label: Browser CDP URL
browser.cdpUrl.help: Remote CDP websocket URL used to attach to an externally managed browser instance. Use this for centralized browser hosts and keep URL access restricted to trusted network paths.

browser.color.label: Browser Accent Color
browser.color.help: Default accent color used for browser profile/UI cues where colored identity hints are displayed. Use consistent colors to help operators identify active browser profile context quickly.

browser.executablePath.label: Browser Executable Path
browser.executablePath.help: Explicit browser executable path when auto-discovery is insufficient for your host environment. Use absolute stable paths so launch behavior stays deterministic across restarts.

browser.headless.label: Browser Headless Mode
browser.headless.help: Forces browser launch in headless mode when the local launcher starts browser instances. Keep headless enabled for server environments and disable only when visible UI debugging is required.

browser.noSandbox.label: Browser No-Sandbox Mode
browser.noSandbox.help: Disables Chromium sandbox isolation flags for environments where sandboxing fails at runtime. Keep this off whenever possible because process isolation protections are reduced.

browser.attachOnly.label: Browser Attach-only Mode
browser.attachOnly.help: Restricts browser mode to attach-only behavior without starting local browser processes. Use this when all browser sessions are externally managed by a remote CDP provider.

browser.defaultProfile.label: Browser Default Profile
browser.defaultProfile.help: Default browser profile name selected when callers do not explicitly choose a profile. Use a stable low-privilege profile as the default to reduce accidental cross-context state use.

browser.profiles.label: Browser Profiles
browser.profiles.help: Named browser profile connection map used for explicit routing to CDP ports or URLs with optional metadata. Keep profile names consistent and avoid overlapping endpoint definitions.

browser.profiles.*.cdpPort.label: Browser Profile CDP Port
browser.profiles.*.cdpPort.help: Per-profile local CDP port used when connecting to browser instances by port instead of URL. Use unique ports per profile to avoid connection collisions.

browser.profiles.*.cdpUrl.label: Browser Profile CDP URL
browser.profiles.*.cdpUrl.help: Per-profile CDP websocket URL used for explicit remote browser routing by profile name. Use this when profile connections terminate on remote hosts or tunnels.

browser.profiles.*.driver.label: Browser Profile Driver
browser.profiles.*.driver.help: Per-profile browser driver mode: "clawd" or "extension" depending on connection/runtime strategy. Use the driver that matches your browser control stack to avoid protocol mismatches.

browser.profiles.*.color.label: Browser Profile Accent Color
browser.profiles.*.color.help: Per-profile accent color for visual differentiation in dashboards and browser-related UI hints. Use distinct colors for high-signal operator recognition of active profiles.

tools.label: Tools
tools.help: Global tool access policy and capability configuration across web, exec, media, messaging, and elevated surfaces. Use this section to constrain risky capabilities before broad rollout.

tools.allow.label: Tool Allowlist
tools.allow.help: Absolute tool allowlist that replaces profile-derived defaults for strict environments. Use this only when you intentionally run a tightly curated subset of tool capabilities.

tools.deny.label: Tool Denylist
tools.deny.help: Global tool denylist that blocks listed tools even when profile or provider rules would allow them. Use deny rules for emergency lockouts and long-term defense-in-depth.

tools.web.label: Web Tools
tools.web.help: Web-tool policy grouping for search/fetch providers, limits, and fallback behavior tuning. Keep enabled settings aligned with API key availability and outbound networking policy.

tools.exec.label: Exec Tool
tools.exec.help: Exec-tool policy grouping for shell execution host, security mode, approval behavior, and runtime bindings. Keep conservative defaults in production and tighten elevated execution paths.

tools.media.image.enabled.label: Enable Image Understanding
tools.media.image.enabled.help: Enable image understanding so attached or referenced images can be interpreted into textual context. Disable if you need text-only operation or want to avoid image-processing cost.

tools.media.image.maxBytes.label: Image Understanding Max Bytes
tools.media.image.maxBytes.help: Maximum accepted image payload size in bytes before the item is skipped or truncated by policy. Keep limits realistic for your provider caps and infrastructure bandwidth.

tools.media.image.maxChars.label: Image Understanding Max Chars
tools.media.image.maxChars.help: Maximum characters returned from image understanding output after model response normalization. Use tighter limits to reduce prompt bloat and larger limits for detail-heavy OCR tasks.

tools.media.image.prompt.label: Image Understanding Prompt
tools.media.image.prompt.help: Instruction template used for image understanding requests to shape extraction style and detail level. Keep prompts deterministic so outputs stay consistent across turns and channels.

tools.media.image.timeoutSeconds.label: Image Understanding Timeout (sec)
tools.media.image.timeoutSeconds.help: Timeout in seconds for each image understanding request before it is aborted. Increase for high-resolution analysis and lower it for latency-sensitive operator workflows.

tools.media.image.attachments.label: Image Understanding Attachment Policy
tools.media.image.attachments.help: Attachment handling policy for image inputs, including which message attachments qualify for image analysis. Use restrictive settings in untrusted channels to reduce unexpected processing.

tools.media.image.models.label: Image Understanding Models
tools.media.image.models.help: Ordered model preferences specifically for image understanding when you want to override shared media models. Put the most reliable multimodal model first to reduce fallback attempts.

tools.media.image.scope.label: Image Understanding Scope
tools.media.image.scope.help: Scope selector for when image understanding is attempted (for example only explicit requests versus broader auto-detection). Keep narrow scope in busy channels to control token and API spend.

tools.media.models.label: Media Understanding Shared Models
tools.media.models.help: Shared fallback model list used by media understanding tools when modality-specific model lists are not set. Keep this aligned with available multimodal providers to avoid runtime fallback churn.

tools.media.concurrency.label: Media Understanding Concurrency
tools.media.concurrency.help: Maximum number of concurrent media understanding operations per turn across image, audio, and video tasks. Lower this in resource-constrained deployments to prevent CPU/network saturation.

tools.media.audio.enabled.label: Enable Audio Understanding
tools.media.audio.enabled.help: Enable audio understanding so voice notes or audio clips can be transcribed/summarized for agent context. Disable when audio ingestion is outside policy or unnecessary for your workflows.

tools.media.audio.maxBytes.label: Audio Understanding Max Bytes
tools.media.audio.maxBytes.help: Maximum accepted audio payload size in bytes before processing is rejected or clipped by policy. Set this based on expected recording length and upstream provider limits.

tools.media.audio.maxChars.label: Audio Understanding Max Chars
tools.media.audio.maxChars.help: Maximum characters retained from audio understanding output to prevent oversized transcript injection. Increase for long-form dictation, or lower to keep conversational turns compact.

tools.media.audio.prompt.label: Audio Understanding Prompt
tools.media.audio.prompt.help: Instruction template guiding audio understanding output style, such as concise summary versus near-verbatim transcript. Keep wording consistent so downstream automations can rely on output format.

tools.media.audio.timeoutSeconds.label: Audio Understanding Timeout (sec)
tools.media.audio.timeoutSeconds.help: Timeout in seconds for audio understanding execution before the operation is cancelled. Use longer timeouts for long recordings and tighter ones for interactive chat responsiveness.

tools.media.audio.language.label: Audio Understanding Language
tools.media.audio.language.help: Preferred language hint for audio understanding/transcription when provider support is available. Set this to improve recognition accuracy for known primary languages.

tools.media.audio.attachments.label: Audio Understanding Attachment Policy
tools.media.audio.attachments.help: Attachment policy for audio inputs indicating which uploaded files are eligible for audio processing. Keep restrictive defaults in mixed-content channels to avoid unintended audio workloads.

tools.media.audio.models.label: Audio Understanding Models
tools.media.audio.models.help: Ordered model preferences specifically for audio understanding, used before shared media model fallback. Choose models optimized for transcription quality in your primary language/domain.

tools.media.audio.scope.label: Audio Understanding Scope
tools.media.audio.scope.help: Scope selector for when audio understanding runs across inbound messages and attachments. Keep focused scopes in high-volume channels to reduce cost and avoid accidental transcription.

tools.media.video.enabled.label: Enable Video Understanding
tools.media.video.enabled.help: Enable video understanding so clips can be summarized into text for downstream reasoning and responses. Disable when processing video is out of policy or too expensive for your deployment.

tools.media.video.maxBytes.label: Video Understanding Max Bytes
tools.media.video.maxBytes.help: Maximum accepted video payload size in bytes before policy rejection or trimming occurs. Tune this to provider and infrastructure limits to avoid repeated timeout/failure loops.

tools.media.video.maxChars.label: Video Understanding Max Chars
tools.media.video.maxChars.help: Maximum characters retained from video understanding output to control prompt growth. Raise for dense scene descriptions and lower when concise summaries are preferred.

tools.media.video.prompt.label: Video Understanding Prompt
tools.media.video.prompt.help: Instruction template for video understanding describing desired summary granularity and focus areas. Keep this stable so output quality remains predictable across model/provider fallbacks.

tools.media.video.timeoutSeconds.label: Video Understanding Timeout (sec)
tools.media.video.timeoutSeconds.help: Timeout in seconds for each video understanding request before cancellation. Use conservative values in interactive channels and longer values for offline or batch-heavy processing.

tools.media.video.attachments.label: Video Understanding Attachment Policy
tools.media.video.attachments.help: Attachment eligibility policy for video analysis, defining which message files can trigger video processing. Keep this explicit in shared channels to prevent accidental large media workloads.

tools.media.video.models.label: Video Understanding Models
tools.media.video.models.help: Ordered model preferences specifically for video understanding before shared media fallback applies. Prioritize models with strong multimodal video support to minimize degraded summaries.

tools.media.video.scope.label: Video Understanding Scope
tools.media.video.scope.help: Scope selector controlling when video understanding is attempted across incoming events. Narrow scope in noisy channels, and broaden only where video interpretation is core to workflow.

tools.links.enabled.label: Enable Link Understanding
tools.links.enabled.help: Enable automatic link understanding pre-processing so URLs can be summarized before agent reasoning. Keep enabled for richer context, and disable when strict minimal processing is required.

tools.links.maxLinks.label: Link Understanding Max Links
tools.links.maxLinks.help: Maximum number of links expanded per turn during link understanding. Use lower values to control latency/cost in chatty threads and higher values when multi-link context is critical.

tools.links.timeoutSeconds.label: Link Understanding Timeout (sec)
tools.links.timeoutSeconds.help: Per-link understanding timeout budget in seconds before unresolved links are skipped. Keep this bounded to avoid long stalls when external sites are slow or unreachable.

tools.links.models.label: Link Understanding Models
tools.links.models.help: Preferred model list for link understanding tasks, evaluated in order as fallbacks when supported. Use lightweight models first for routine summarization and heavier models only when needed.

tools.links.scope.label: Link Understanding Scope
tools.links.scope.help: Controls when link understanding runs relative to conversation context and message type. Keep scope conservative to avoid unnecessary fetches on messages where links are not actionable.

tools.profile.label: Tool Profile
tools.profile.help: Global tool profile name used to select a predefined tool policy baseline before applying allow/deny overrides. Use this for consistent environment posture across agents and keep profile names stable.

tools.alsoAllow.label: Tool Allowlist Additions
tools.alsoAllow.help: Extra tool allowlist entries merged on top of the selected tool profile and default policy. Keep this list small and explicit so audits can quickly identify intentional policy exceptions.

agents.list[].tools.profile.label: Agent Tool Profile
agents.list[].tools.profile.help: Per-agent override for tool profile selection when one agent needs a different capability baseline. Use this sparingly so policy differences across agents stay intentional and reviewable.

agents.list[].tools.alsoAllow.label: Agent Tool Allowlist Additions
agents.list[].tools.alsoAllow.help: Per-agent additive allowlist for tools on top of global and profile policy. Keep narrow to avoid accidental privilege expansion on specialized agents.

tools.byProvider.label: Tool Policy by Provider
tools.byProvider.help: Per-provider tool allow/deny overrides keyed by channel/provider ID to tailor capabilities by surface. Use this when one provider needs stricter controls than global tool policy.

agents.list[].tools.byProvider.label: Agent Tool Policy by Provider
agents.list[].tools.byProvider.help: Per-agent provider-specific tool policy overrides for channel-scoped capability control. Use this when a single agent needs tighter restrictions on one provider than others.

tools.exec.applyPatch.enabled.label: Enable apply_patch
tools.exec.applyPatch.enabled.help: Experimental. Enables apply_patch for OpenAI models when allowed by tool policy.

tools.exec.applyPatch.workspaceOnly.label: apply_patch Workspace-Only
tools.exec.applyPatch.workspaceOnly.help: Restrict apply_patch paths to the workspace directory (default: true). Set false to allow writing outside the workspace (dangerous).

tools.exec.applyPatch.allowModels.label: apply_patch Model Allowlist
tools.exec.applyPatch.allowModels.help: Optional allowlist of model ids (e.g. "gpt-5.2" or "openai/gpt-5.2").

tools.loopDetection.enabled.label: Tool-loop Detection
tools.loopDetection.enabled.help: Enable repetitive tool-call loop detection and backoff safety checks (default: false).

tools.loopDetection.historySize.label: Tool-loop History Size
tools.loopDetection.historySize.help: Tool history window size for loop detection (default: 30).

tools.loopDetection.warningThreshold.label: Tool-loop Warning Threshold
tools.loopDetection.warningThreshold.help: Warning threshold for repetitive patterns when detector is enabled (default: 10).

tools.loopDetection.criticalThreshold.label: Tool-loop Critical Threshold
tools.loopDetection.criticalThreshold.help: Critical threshold for repetitive patterns when detector is enabled (default: 20).

tools.loopDetection.detectors.genericRep.label: Tool-loop Generic Repeat Detection
tools.loopDetection.detectors.genericRep.help: Enable generic repeated same-tool/same-params loop detection (default: true).

tools.loopDetection.detectors.knownPollN.label: Tool-loop Poll No-Progress Detection
tools.loopDetection.detectors.knownPollN.help: Enable known poll tool no-progress loop detection (default: true).

tools.fs.workspaceOnly.label: Workspace-only FS tools
tools.fs.workspaceOnly.help: Restrict filesystem tools (read/write/edit/apply_patch) to the workspace directory (default: false).

tools.sessions.visibility.label: Session Tools Visibility
tools.sessions.visibility.help: Controls which sessions can be targeted by sessions_list/sessions_history/sessions_send. ("tree" default = current session + spawned subagent sessions; "self" = only current; "agent" = any session in the current agent id; "all" = any session; cross-agent still requires tools.agentToAgent).

tools.exec.notifyOnExit.label: Exec Notify On Exit
tools.exec.notifyOnExit.help: When true (default), backgrounded exec sessions on exit and node exec lifecycle events enqueue a system event and request a heartbeat.

tools.exec.notifyOnExitEmptySuccess.label: Exec Notify On Empty Success
tools.exec.notifyOnExitEmptySuccess.help: When true, successful backgrounded exec exits with empty output still enqueue a completion system event (default: false).

tools.exec.approvalRunningNoticeMs.label: Exec Approval Running Notice (ms)
tools.exec.approvalRunningNoticeMs.help: Delay in milliseconds before showing an in-progress notice after an exec approval is granted. Increase to reduce flicker for fast commands, or lower for quicker operator feedback.

tools.exec.host.label: Exec Host
tools.exec.host.help: Selects execution host strategy for shell commands, typically controlling local vs delegated execution environment. Use the safest host mode that still satisfies your automation requirements.

tools.exec.security.label: Exec Security
tools.exec.security.help: Execution security posture selector controlling sandbox/approval expectations for command execution. Keep strict security mode for untrusted prompts and relax only for trusted operator workflows.

tools.exec.ask.label: Exec Ask
tools.exec.ask.help: Approval strategy for when exec commands require human confirmation before running. Use stricter ask behavior in shared channels and lower-friction settings in private operator contexts.

tools.exec.node.label: Exec Node Binding
tools.exec.node.help: Node binding configuration for exec tooling when command execution is delegated through connected nodes. Use explicit node binding only when multi-node routing is required.

tools.agentToAgent.label: Agent-to-Agent Tool Access
tools.agentToAgent.help: Policy for allowing agent-to-agent tool calls and constraining which target agents can be reached. Keep disabled or tightly scoped unless cross-agent orchestration is intentionally enabled.

tools.agentToAgent.enabled.label: Enable Agent-to-Agent Tool
tools.agentToAgent.enabled.help: Enables the agent_to_agent tool surface so one agent can invoke another agent at runtime. Keep off in simple deployments and enable only when orchestration value outweighs complexity.

tools.agentToAgent.allow.label: Agent-to-Agent Target Allowlist
tools.agentToAgent.allow.help: Allowlist of target agent IDs permitted for agent_to_agent calls when orchestration is enabled. Use explicit allowlists to avoid uncontrolled cross-agent call graphs.

tools.elevated.label: Elevated Tool Access
tools.elevated.help: Elevated tool access controls for privileged command surfaces that should only be reachable from trusted senders. Keep disabled unless operator workflows explicitly require elevated actions.

tools.elevated.enabled.label: Enable Elevated Tool Access
tools.elevated.enabled.help: Enables elevated tool execution path when sender and policy checks pass. Keep disabled in public/shared channels and enable only for trusted owner-operated contexts.

tools.elevated.allowFrom.label: Elevated Tool Allow Rules
tools.elevated.allowFrom.help: Sender allow rules for elevated tools, usually keyed by channel/provider identity formats. Use narrow, explicit identities so elevated commands cannot be triggered by unintended users.

tools.subagents.label: Subagent Tool Policy
tools.subagents.help: Tool policy wrapper for spawned subagents to restrict or expand tool availability compared to parent defaults. Use this to keep delegated agent capabilities scoped to task intent.

tools.subagents.tools.label: Subagent Tool Allow/Deny Policy
tools.subagents.tools.help: Allow/deny tool policy applied to spawned subagent runtimes for per-subagent hardening. Keep this narrower than parent scope when subagents run semi-autonomous workflows.

tools.sandbox.label: Sandbox Tool Policy
tools.sandbox.help: Tool policy wrapper for sandboxed agent executions so sandbox runs can have distinct capability boundaries. Use this to enforce stronger safety in sandbox contexts.

tools.sandbox.tools.label: Sandbox Tool Allow/Deny Policy
tools.sandbox.tools.help: Allow/deny tool policy applied when agents run in sandboxed execution environments. Keep policies minimal so sandbox tasks cannot escalate into unnecessary external actions.

tools.exec.pathPrepend.label: Exec PATH Prepend
tools.exec.pathPrepend.help: Directories to prepend to PATH for exec runs (gateway/sandbox).

tools.exec.safeBins.label: Exec Safe Bins
tools.exec.safeBins.help: Allow stdin-only safe binaries to run without explicit allowlist entries.

tools.exec.safeBinTrustedDirs.label: Exec Safe Bin Trusted Dirs
tools.exec.safeBinTrustedDirs.help: Additional explicit directories trusted for safe-bin path checks (PATH entries are never auto-trusted).

tools.exec.safeBinProfiles.label: Exec Safe Bin Profiles
tools.exec.safeBinProfiles.help: Optional per-binary safe-bin profiles (positional limits + allowed/denied flags).

approvals.label: Approvals
approvals.help: Approval routing controls for forwarding exec approval requests to chat destinations outside the originating session. Keep this disabled unless operators need explicit out-of-band approval visibility.

approvals.exec.label: Exec Approval Forwarding
approvals.exec.help: Groups exec-approval forwarding behavior including enablement, routing mode, filters, and explicit targets. Configure here when approval prompts must reach operational channels instead of only the origin thread.

approvals.exec.enabled.label: Forward Exec Approvals
approvals.exec.enabled.help: Enables forwarding of exec approval requests to configured delivery destinations (default: false). Keep disabled in low-risk setups and enable only when human approval responders need channel-visible prompts.

approvals.exec.mode.label: Approval Forwarding Mode
approvals.exec.mode.help: Controls where approval prompts are sent: "session" uses origin chat, "targets" uses configured targets, and "both" sends to both paths. Use "session" as baseline and expand only when operational workflow requires redundancy.

approvals.exec.agentFilter.label: Approval Agent Filter
approvals.exec.agentFilter.help: Optional allowlist of agent IDs eligible for forwarded approvals, for example `["primary", "ops-agent"]`. Use this to limit forwarding blast radius and avoid notifying channels for unrelated agents.

approvals.exec.sessionFilter.label: Approval Session Filter
approvals.exec.sessionFilter.help: Optional session-key filters matched as substring or regex-style patterns, for example `["discord:", "^agent:ops:"]`. Use narrow patterns so only intended approval contexts are forwarded to shared destinations.

approvals.exec.targets.label: Approval Forwarding Targets
approvals.exec.targets.help: Explicit delivery targets used when forwarding mode includes targets, each with channel and destination details. Keep target lists least-privilege and validate each destination before enabling broad forwarding.

approvals.exec.targets[].channel.label: Approval Target Channel
approvals.exec.targets[].channel.help: Channel/provider ID used for forwarded approval delivery, such as discord, slack, or a plugin channel id. Use valid channel IDs only so approvals do not silently fail due to unknown routes.

approvals.exec.targets[].to.label: Approval Target Destination
approvals.exec.targets[].to.help: Destination identifier inside the target channel (channel ID, user ID, or thread root depending on provider). Verify semantics per provider because destination format differs across channel integrations.

approvals.exec.targets[].accountId.label: Approval Target Account ID
approvals.exec.targets[].accountId.help: Optional account selector for multi-account channel setups when approvals must route through a specific account context. Use this only when the target channel has multiple configured identities.

approvals.exec.targets[].threadId.label: Approval Target Thread ID
approvals.exec.targets[].threadId.help: Optional thread/topic target for channels that support threaded delivery of forwarded approvals. Use this to keep approval traffic contained in operational threads instead of main channels.

tools.message.allowCrossContextSend.label: Allow Cross-Context Messaging
tools.message.allowCrossContextSend.help: Legacy override: allow cross-context sends across all providers.

tools.message.crossContext.allowWithinPr.label: Allow Cross-Context (Same Provider)
tools.message.crossContext.allowWithinPr.help: Allow sends to other channels within the same provider (default: true).

tools.message.crossContext.allowAcrossPr.label: Allow Cross-Context (Across Providers)
tools.message.crossContext.allowAcrossPr.help: Allow sends across different providers (default: false).

tools.message.crossContext.marker.enable.label: Cross-Context Marker
tools.message.crossContext.marker.enable.help: Add a visible origin marker when sending cross-context (default: true).

tools.web.search.enabled.label: Enable Web Search Tool
tools.web.search.enabled.help: Enable the web_search tool (requires a provider API key).

tools.web.search.provider.label: Web Search Provider
tools.web.search.provider.help: Search provider ("brave", "perplexity", "grok", or "gemini"). Auto-detected from available API keys if omitted.

tools.web.search.apiKey.label: Brave Search API Key
tools.web.search.apiKey.help: Brave Search API key (fallback: BRAVE_API_KEY env var).

tools.web.search.maxResults.label: Web Search Max Results
tools.web.search.maxResults.help: Default number of results to return (1-10).

tools.web.search.timeoutSeconds.label: Web Search Timeout (sec)
tools.web.search.timeoutSeconds.help: Timeout in seconds for web_search requests.

tools.web.search.cacheTtlMinutes.label: Web Search Cache TTL (min)
tools.web.search.cacheTtlMinutes.help: Cache TTL in minutes for web_search results.

tools.web.search.perplexity.apiKey.label: Perplexity API Key
tools.web.search.perplexity.apiKey.help: Perplexity or OpenRouter API key (fallback: PERPLEXITY_API_KEY or OPENROUTER_API_KEY env var).

tools.web.search.perplexity.baseUrl.label: Perplexity Base URL
tools.web.search.perplexity.baseUrl.help: Perplexity base URL override (default: https://openrouter.ai/api/v1 or https://api.perplexity.ai).

tools.web.search.gemini.apiKey.label: Gemini Search API Key
tools.web.search.gemini.apiKey.help: Gemini API key for Google Search grounding (fallback: GEMINI_API_KEY env var).

tools.web.search.grok.apiKey.label: Grok Search API Key
tools.web.search.grok.apiKey.help: Grok (xAI) API key (fallback: XAI_API_KEY env var).

tools.web.fetch.enabled.label: Enable Web Fetch Tool
tools.web.fetch.enabled.help: Enable the web_fetch tool (lightweight HTTP fetch).

tools.web.fetch.maxCharsCap.label: Web Fetch Hard Max Chars
tools.web.fetch.maxCharsCap.help: Hard cap for web_fetch maxChars (applies to config and tool calls).

tools.web.fetch.timeoutSeconds.label: Web Fetch Timeout (sec)
tools.web.fetch.timeoutSeconds.help: Timeout in seconds for web_fetch requests.

tools.web.fetch.cacheTtlMinutes.label: Web Fetch Cache TTL (min)
tools.web.fetch.cacheTtlMinutes.help: Cache TTL in minutes for web_fetch results.

tools.web.fetch.userAgent.label: Web Fetch User-Agent
tools.web.fetch.userAgent.help: Override User-Agent header for web_fetch requests.

tools.web.fetch.readability.label: Web Fetch Readability Extraction
tools.web.fetch.readability.help: Use Readability to extract main content from HTML (fallbacks to basic HTML cleanup).

tools.web.fetch.firecrawl.enabled.label: Enable Firecrawl Fallback
tools.web.fetch.firecrawl.enabled.help: Enable Firecrawl fallback for web_fetch (if configured).

tools.web.fetch.firecrawl.apiKey.label: Firecrawl API Key
tools.web.fetch.firecrawl.apiKey.help: Firecrawl API key (fallback: FIRECRAWL_API_KEY env var).

tools.web.fetch.firecrawl.baseUrl.label: Firecrawl Base URL
tools.web.fetch.firecrawl.baseUrl.help: Firecrawl base URL (e.g. https://api.firecrawl.dev or custom endpoint).

tools.web.fetch.firecrawl.onlyMainConten.label: Firecrawl Main Content Only
tools.web.fetch.firecrawl.onlyMainConten.help: When true, Firecrawl returns only the main content (default: true).

tools.web.fetch.firecrawl.maxAgeMs.label: Firecrawl Cache Max Age (ms)
tools.web.fetch.firecrawl.maxAgeMs.help: Firecrawl maxAge (ms) for cached results when supported by the API.

tools.web.fetch.firecrawl.timeoutSeconds.label: Firecrawl Timeout (sec)
tools.web.fetch.firecrawl.timeoutSeconds.help: Timeout in seconds for Firecrawl requests.

gateway.controlUi.basePath.label: Control UI Base Path
gateway.controlUi.basePath.help: Optional URL prefix where the Control UI is served (e.g. /openclaw).

gateway.controlUi.root.label: Control UI Assets Root
gateway.controlUi.root.help: Optional filesystem root for Control UI assets (defaults to dist/control-ui).

gateway.controlUi.allowedOrigins.label: Control UI Allowed Origins
gateway.controlUi.allowedOrigins.help: Allowed browser origins for Control UI/WebChat websocket connections (full origins only, e.g. https://control.example.com).

gateway.controlUi.allowInsecureAuth.label: Insecure Control UI Auth Toggle
gateway.controlUi.allowInsecureAuth.help: Loosens strict browser auth checks for Control UI when you must run a non-standard setup. Keep this off unless you trust your network and proxy path, because impersonation risk is higher.

gateway.controlUi.dangerouslyDisableDevi.label: Dangerously Disable Control UI Device Auth
gateway.controlUi.dangerouslyDisableDevi.help: Disables Control UI device identity checks and relies on token/password only. Use only for short-lived debugging on trusted networks, then turn it off immediately.

gateway.reload.mode.label: Config Reload Mode
gateway.reload.mode.help: Controls how config edits are applied: "off" ignores live edits, "restart" always restarts, "hot" applies in-process, and "hybrid" tries hot then restarts if required. Keep "hybrid" for safest routine updates.

gateway.reload.debounceMs.label: Config Reload Debounce (ms)
gateway.reload.debounceMs.help: Debounce window (ms) before applying config changes.

gateway.nodes.browser.mode.label: Gateway Node Browser Mode
gateway.nodes.browser.mode.help: Node browser routing ("auto" = pick single connected browser node, "manual" = require node param, "off" = disable).

gateway.nodes.browser.node.label: Gateway Node Browser Pin
gateway.nodes.browser.node.help: Pin browser routing to a specific node id or name (optional).

gateway.nodes.allowCommands.label: Gateway Node Allowlist (Extra Commands)
gateway.nodes.allowCommands.help: Extra node.invoke commands to allow beyond the gateway defaults (array of command strings). Enabling dangerous commands here is a security-sensitive override and is flagged by `openclaw security audit`.

gateway.nodes.denyCommands.label: Gateway Node Denylist
gateway.nodes.denyCommands.help: Commands to block even if present in node claims or default allowlist.

nodeHost.label: Node Host
nodeHost.help: Node host controls for features exposed from this gateway node to other nodes or clients. Keep defaults unless you intentionally proxy local capabilities across your node network.

nodeHost.browserProxy.label: Node Browser Proxy
nodeHost.browserProxy.help: Groups browser-proxy settings for exposing local browser control through node routing. Enable only when remote node workflows need your local browser profiles.

nodeHost.browserProxy.enabled.label: Node Browser Proxy Enabled
nodeHost.browserProxy.enabled.help: Expose the local browser control server through node proxy routing so remote clients can use this host's browser capabilities. Keep disabled unless remote automation explicitly depends on it.

nodeHost.browserProxy.allowProfiles.label: Node Browser Proxy Allowed Profiles
nodeHost.browserProxy.allowProfiles.help: Optional allowlist of browser profile names exposed through node proxy routing. Leave empty to expose all configured profiles, or use a tight list to enforce least-privilege profile access.

media.label: Media
media.help: Top-level media behavior shared across providers and tools that handle inbound files. Keep defaults unless you need stable filenames for external processing pipelines.

media.preserveFilenames.label: Preserve Media Filenames
media.preserveFilenames.help: When enabled, uploaded media keeps its original filename instead of a generated temp-safe name. Turn this on when downstream automations depend on stable names, and leave off to reduce accidental filename leakage.

audio.label: Audio
audio.help: Global audio ingestion settings used before higher-level tools process speech or media content. Configure this when you need deterministic transcription behavior for voice notes and clips.

audio.transcription.label: Audio Transcription
audio.transcription.help: Command-based transcription settings for converting audio files into text before agent handling. Keep a simple, deterministic command path here so failures are easy to diagnose in logs.

audio.transcription.command.label: Audio Transcription Command
audio.transcription.command.help: Executable + args used to transcribe audio (first token must be a safe binary/path), for example `["whisper-cli", "--model", "small", "{input}"]`. Prefer a pinned command so runtime environments behave consistently.

audio.transcription.timeoutSeconds.label: Audio Transcription Timeout (sec)
audio.transcription.timeoutSeconds.help: Maximum time allowed for the transcription command to finish before it is aborted. Increase this for longer recordings, and keep it tight in latency-sensitive deployments.

bindings.label: Bindings
bindings.help: Static routing bindings that pin inbound conversations to specific agent IDs by match rules. Use bindings for deterministic ownership when dynamic routing should not decide.

bindings[].agentId.label: Binding Agent ID
bindings[].agentId.help: Target agent ID that receives traffic when the corresponding binding match rule is satisfied. Use valid configured agent IDs only so routing does not fail at runtime.

bindings[].match.label: Binding Match Rule
bindings[].match.help: Match rule object for deciding when a binding applies, including channel and optional account/peer constraints. Keep rules narrow to avoid accidental agent takeover across contexts.

bindings[].match.channel.label: Binding Channel
bindings[].match.channel.help: Channel/provider identifier this binding applies to, such as `telegram`, `discord`, or a plugin channel ID. Use the configured channel key exactly so binding evaluation works reliably.

bindings[].match.accountId.label: Binding Account ID
bindings[].match.accountId.help: Optional account selector for multi-account channel setups so the binding applies only to one identity. Use this when account scoping is required for the route and leave unset otherwise.

bindings[].match.peer.label: Binding Peer Match
bindings[].match.peer.help: Optional peer matcher for specific conversations including peer kind and peer id. Use this when only one direct/group/channel target should be pinned to an agent.

bindings[].match.peer.kind.label: Binding Peer Kind
bindings[].match.peer.kind.help: Peer conversation type: "direct", "group", "channel", or legacy "dm" (deprecated alias for direct). Prefer "direct" for new configs and keep kind aligned with channel semantics.

bindings[].match.peer.id.label: Binding Peer ID
bindings[].match.peer.id.help: Conversation identifier used with peer matching, such as a chat ID, channel ID, or group ID from the provider. Keep this exact to avoid silent non-matches.

bindings[].match.guildId.label: Binding Guild ID
bindings[].match.guildId.help: Optional Discord-style guild/server ID constraint for binding evaluation in multi-server deployments. Use this when the same peer identifiers can appear across different guilds.

bindings[].match.teamId.label: Binding Team ID
bindings[].match.teamId.help: Optional team/workspace ID constraint used by providers that scope chats under teams. Add this when you need bindings isolated to one workspace context.

bindings[].match.roles.label: Binding Roles
bindings[].match.roles.help: Optional role-based filter list used by providers that attach roles to chat context. Use this to route privileged or operational role traffic to specialized agents.

broadcast.label: Broadcast
broadcast.help: Broadcast routing map for sending the same outbound message to multiple peer IDs per source conversation. Keep this minimal and audited because one source can fan out to many destinations.

broadcast.strategy.label: Broadcast Strategy
broadcast.strategy.help: Delivery order for broadcast fan-out: "parallel" sends to all targets concurrently, while "sequential" sends one-by-one. Use "parallel" for speed and "sequential" for stricter ordering/backpressure control.

broadcast.*.label: Broadcast Destination List
broadcast.*.help: Per-source broadcast destination list where each key is a source peer ID and the value is an array of destination peer IDs. Keep lists intentional to avoid accidental message amplification.

skills.load.watch.label: Watch Skills
skills.load.watch.help: Enable filesystem watching for skill-definition changes so updates can be applied without full process restart. Keep enabled in development workflows and disable in immutable production images.

skills.load.watchDebounceMs.label: Skills Watch Debounce (ms)
skills.load.watchDebounceMs.help: Debounce window in milliseconds for coalescing rapid skill file changes before reload logic runs. Increase to reduce reload churn on frequent writes, or lower for faster edit feedback.

agents.defaults.workspace.label: Workspace
agents.defaults.workspace.help: Default workspace path exposed to agent runtime tools for filesystem context and repo-aware behavior. Set this explicitly when running from wrappers so path resolution stays deterministic.

agents.defaults.repoRoot.label: Repo Root
agents.defaults.repoRoot.help: Optional repository root shown in the system prompt runtime line (overrides auto-detect).

agents.defaults.bootstrapMaxChars.label: Bootstrap Max Chars
agents.defaults.bootstrapMaxChars.help: Max characters of each workspace bootstrap file injected into the system prompt before truncation (default: 20000).

agents.defaults.bootstrapTotalMaxChars.label: Bootstrap Total Max Chars
agents.defaults.bootstrapTotalMaxChars.help: Max total characters across all injected workspace bootstrap files (default: 150000).

agents.defaults.envelopeTimezone.label: Envelope Timezone
agents.defaults.envelopeTimezone.help: Timezone for message envelopes ("utc", "local", "user", or an IANA timezone string).

agents.defaults.envelopeTimestamp.label: Envelope Timestamp
agents.defaults.envelopeTimestamp.help: Include absolute timestamps in message envelopes ("on" or "off").

agents.defaults.envelopeElapsed.label: Envelope Elapsed
agents.defaults.envelopeElapsed.help: Include elapsed time in message envelopes ("on" or "off").

agents.defaults.memorySearch.label: Memory Search
agents.defaults.memorySearch.help: Vector search over MEMORY.md and memory/*.md (per-agent overrides supported).

agents.defaults.memorySearch.enabled.label: Enable Memory Search
agents.defaults.memorySearch.enabled.help: Master toggle for memory search indexing and retrieval behavior on this agent profile. Keep enabled for semantic recall, and disable when you want fully stateless responses.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.sources.label: Memory Search Sources
agents.defaults.memorySearch.sources.help: Chooses which sources are indexed: "memory" reads MEMORY.md + memory files, and "sessions" includes transcript history. Keep ["memory"] unless you need recall from prior chat transcripts.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.extraPaths.label: Extra Memory Paths
agents.defaults.memorySearch.extraPaths.help: Adds extra directories or .md files to the memory index beyond default memory files. Use this when key reference docs live elsewhere in your repo; keep paths small and intentional to avoid noisy recall.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.experimenta.label: Memory Search Session Index (Experimental)
agents.defaults.memorySearch.experimenta.help: Indexes session transcripts into memory search so responses can reference prior chat turns. Keep this off unless transcript recall is needed, because indexing cost and storage usage both increase.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.provider.label: Memory Search Provider
agents.defaults.memorySearch.provider.help: Selects the embedding backend used to build/query memory vectors: "openai", "gemini", "voyage", "mistral", or "local". Keep your most reliable provider here and configure fallback for resilience.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.remote.base.label: Remote Embedding Base URL
agents.defaults.memorySearch.remote.base.help: Overrides the embedding API endpoint, such as an OpenAI-compatible proxy or custom Gemini base URL. Use this only when routing through your own gateway or vendor endpoint; keep provider defaults otherwise.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.remote.apiK.label: Remote Embedding API Key
agents.defaults.memorySearch.remote.apiK.help: Supplies a dedicated API key for remote embedding calls used by memory indexing and query-time embeddings. Use this when memory embeddings should use different credentials than global defaults or environment variables.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.remote.head.label: Remote Embedding Headers
agents.defaults.memorySearch.remote.head.help: Adds custom HTTP headers to remote embedding requests, merged with provider defaults. Use this for proxy auth and tenant routing headers, and keep values minimal to avoid leaking sensitive metadata.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.remote.batc.label: Remote Batch Embedding Enabled
agents.defaults.memorySearch.remote.batc.help: Enables provider batch APIs for embedding jobs when supported (OpenAI/Gemini), improving throughput on larger index runs. Keep this enabled unless debugging provider batch failures or running very small workloads.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.remote.batc.label: Remote Batch Wait for Completion
agents.defaults.memorySearch.remote.batc.help: Waits for batch embedding jobs to fully finish before the indexing operation completes. Keep this enabled for deterministic indexing state; disable only if you accept delayed consistency.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.remote.batc.label: Remote Batch Concurrency
agents.defaults.memorySearch.remote.batc.help: Limits how many embedding batch jobs run at the same time during indexing (default: 2). Increase carefully for faster bulk indexing, but watch provider rate limits and queue errors.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.remote.batc.label: Remote Batch Poll Interval (ms)
agents.defaults.memorySearch.remote.batc.help: Controls how often the system polls provider APIs for batch job status in milliseconds (default: 2000). Use longer intervals to reduce API chatter, or shorter intervals for faster completion detection.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.remote.batc.label: Remote Batch Timeout (min)
agents.defaults.memorySearch.remote.batc.help: Sets the maximum wait time for a full embedding batch operation in minutes (default: 60). Increase for very large corpora or slower providers, and lower it to fail fast in automation-heavy flows.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.model.label: Memory Search Model
agents.defaults.memorySearch.model.help: Embedding model override used by the selected memory provider when a non-default model is required. Set this only when you need explicit recall quality/cost tuning beyond provider defaults.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.fallback.label: Memory Search Fallback
agents.defaults.memorySearch.fallback.help: Backup provider used when primary embeddings fail: "openai", "gemini", "voyage", "mistral", "local", or "none". Set a real fallback for production reliability; use "none" only if you prefer explicit failures.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.local.model.label: Local Embedding Model Path
agents.defaults.memorySearch.local.model.help: Specifies the local embedding model source for local memory search, such as a GGUF file path or `hf:` URI. Use this only when provider is `local`, and verify model compatibility before large index rebuilds.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.store.path.label: Memory Search Index Path
agents.defaults.memorySearch.store.path.help: Sets where the SQLite memory index is stored on disk for each agent. Keep the default `~/.openclaw/memory/{agentId}.sqlite` unless you need custom storage placement or backup policy alignment.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.store.vecto.label: Memory Search Vector Index
agents.defaults.memorySearch.store.vecto.help: Enables the sqlite-vec extension used for vector similarity queries in memory search (default: true). Keep this enabled for normal semantic recall; disable only for debugging or fallback-only operation.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.store.vecto.label: Memory Search Vector Extension Path
agents.defaults.memorySearch.store.vecto.help: Overrides the auto-discovered sqlite-vec extension library path (`.dylib`, `.so`, or `.dll`). Use this when your runtime cannot find sqlite-vec automatically or you pin a known-good build.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.chunking.to.label: Memory Chunk Tokens
agents.defaults.memorySearch.chunking.to.help: Chunk size in tokens used when splitting memory sources before embedding/indexing. Increase for broader context per chunk, or lower to improve precision on pinpoint lookups.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.chunking.ov.label: Memory Chunk Overlap Tokens
agents.defaults.memorySearch.chunking.ov.help: Token overlap between adjacent memory chunks to preserve context continuity near split boundaries. Use modest overlap to reduce boundary misses without inflating index size too aggressively.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.sync.onSess.label: Index on Session Start
agents.defaults.memorySearch.sync.onSess.help: Triggers a memory index sync when a session starts so early turns see fresh memory content. Keep enabled when startup freshness matters more than initial turn latency.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.sync.onSear.label: Index on Search (Lazy)
agents.defaults.memorySearch.sync.onSear.help: Uses lazy sync by scheduling reindex on search after content changes are detected. Keep enabled for lower idle overhead, or disable if you require pre-synced indexes before any query.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.sync.watch.label: Watch Memory Files
agents.defaults.memorySearch.sync.watch.help: Watches memory files and schedules index updates from file-change events (chokidar). Enable for near-real-time freshness; disable on very large workspaces if watch churn is too noisy.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.sync.watchD.label: Memory Watch Debounce (ms)
agents.defaults.memorySearch.sync.watchD.help: Debounce window in milliseconds for coalescing rapid file-watch events before reindex runs. Increase to reduce churn on frequently-written files, or lower for faster freshness.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.sync.sessio.label: Session Delta Bytes
agents.defaults.memorySearch.sync.sessio.help: Requires at least this many newly appended bytes before session transcript changes trigger reindex (default: 100000). Increase to reduce frequent small reindexes, or lower for faster transcript freshness.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.sync.sessio.label: Session Delta Messages
agents.defaults.memorySearch.sync.sessio.help: Requires at least this many appended transcript messages before reindex is triggered (default: 50). Lower this for near-real-time transcript recall, or raise it to reduce indexing churn.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.maxRe.label: Memory Search Max Results
agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.maxRe.help: Maximum number of memory hits returned from search before downstream reranking and prompt injection. Raise for broader recall, or lower for tighter prompts and faster responses.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.minSc.label: Memory Search Min Score
agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.minSc.help: Minimum relevance score threshold for including memory results in final recall output. Increase to reduce weak/noisy matches, or lower when you need more permissive retrieval.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.hybri.label: Memory Search Hybrid
agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.hybri.help: Combines BM25 keyword matching with vector similarity for better recall on mixed exact + semantic queries. Keep enabled unless you are isolating ranking behavior for troubleshooting.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.hybri.label: Memory Search Vector Weight
agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.hybri.help: Controls how strongly semantic similarity influences hybrid ranking (0-1). Increase when paraphrase matching matters more than exact terms; decrease for stricter keyword emphasis.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.hybri.label: Memory Search Text Weight
agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.hybri.help: Controls how strongly BM25 keyword relevance influences hybrid ranking (0-1). Increase for exact-term matching; decrease when semantic matches should rank higher.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.hybri.label: Memory Search Hybrid Candidate Multiplier
agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.hybri.help: Expands the candidate pool before reranking (default: 4). Raise this for better recall on noisy corpora, but expect more compute and slightly slower searches.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.hybri.label: Memory Search MMR Re-ranking
agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.hybri.help: Adds MMR reranking to diversify results and reduce near-duplicate snippets in a single answer window. Enable when recall looks repetitive; keep off for strict score ordering.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.hybri.label: Memory Search MMR Lambda
agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.hybri.help: Sets MMR relevance-vs-diversity balance (0 = most diverse, 1 = most relevant, default: 0.7). Lower values reduce repetition; higher values keep tightly relevant but may duplicate.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.hybri.label: Memory Search Temporal Decay
agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.hybri.help: Applies recency decay so newer memory can outrank older memory when scores are close. Enable when timeliness matters; keep off for timeless reference knowledge.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.hybri.label: Memory Search Temporal Decay Half-life (Days)
agents.defaults.memorySearch.query.hybri.help: Controls how fast older memory loses rank when temporal decay is enabled (half-life in days, default: 30). Lower values prioritize recent context more aggressively.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.cache.enabl.label: Memory Search Embedding Cache
agents.defaults.memorySearch.cache.enabl.help: Caches computed chunk embeddings in SQLite so reindexing and incremental updates run faster (default: true). Keep this enabled unless investigating cache correctness or minimizing disk usage.

agents.defaults.memorySearch.cache.maxEn.label: Memory Search Embedding Cache Max Entries
agents.defaults.memorySearch.cache.maxEn.help: Sets a best-effort upper bound on cached embeddings kept in SQLite for memory search. Use this when controlling disk growth matters more than peak reindex speed.

memory.backend.label: Memory Backend
memory.backend.help: Selects the global memory engine: "builtin" uses OpenClaw memory internals, while "qmd" uses the QMD sidecar pipeline. Keep "builtin" unless you intentionally operate QMD.

memory.citations.label: Memory Citations Mode
memory.citations.help: Controls citation visibility in replies: "auto" shows citations when useful, "on" always shows them, and "off" hides them. Keep "auto" for a balanced signal-to-noise default.

memory.qmd.command.label: QMD Binary
memory.qmd.command.help: Sets the executable path for the `qmd` binary used by the QMD backend (default: resolved from PATH). Use an explicit absolute path when multiple qmd installs exist or PATH differs across environments.

memory.qmd.mcporter.label: QMD MCPorter
memory.qmd.mcporter.help: Routes QMD work through mcporter (MCP runtime) instead of spawning `qmd` for each call. Use this when cold starts are expensive on large models; keep direct process mode for simpler local setups.

memory.qmd.mcporter.enabled.label: QMD MCPorter Enabled
memory.qmd.mcporter.enabled.help: Routes QMD through an mcporter daemon instead of spawning qmd per request, reducing cold-start overhead for larger models. Keep disabled unless mcporter is installed and configured.

memory.qmd.mcporter.serverName.label: QMD MCPorter Server Name
memory.qmd.mcporter.serverName.help: Names the mcporter server target used for QMD calls (default: qmd). Change only when your mcporter setup uses a custom server name for qmd mcp keep-alive.

memory.qmd.mcporter.startDaemon.label: QMD MCPorter Start Daemon
memory.qmd.mcporter.startDaemon.help: Automatically starts the mcporter daemon when mcporter-backed QMD mode is enabled (default: true). Keep enabled unless process lifecycle is managed externally by your service supervisor.

memory.qmd.searchMode.label: QMD Search Mode
memory.qmd.searchMode.help: Selects the QMD retrieval path: "query" uses standard query flow, "search" uses search-oriented retrieval, and "vsearch" emphasizes vector retrieval. Keep default unless tuning relevance quality.

memory.qmd.includeDefaultMemory.label: QMD Include Default Memory
memory.qmd.includeDefaultMemory.help: Automatically indexes default memory files (MEMORY.md and memory/**/*.md) into QMD collections. Keep enabled unless you want indexing controlled only through explicit custom paths.

memory.qmd.paths.label: QMD Extra Paths
memory.qmd.paths.help: Adds custom directories or files to include in QMD indexing, each with an optional name and glob pattern. Use this for project-specific knowledge locations that are outside default memory paths.

memory.qmd.paths.path.label: QMD Path
memory.qmd.paths.path.help: Defines the root location QMD should scan, using an absolute path or `~`-relative path. Use stable directories so collection identity does not drift across environments.

memory.qmd.paths.pattern.label: QMD Path Pattern
memory.qmd.paths.pattern.help: Filters files under each indexed root using a glob pattern, with default `**/*.md`. Use narrower patterns to reduce noise and indexing cost when directories contain mixed file types.

memory.qmd.paths.name.label: QMD Path Name
memory.qmd.paths.name.help: Sets a stable collection name for an indexed path instead of deriving it from filesystem location. Use this when paths vary across machines but you want consistent collection identity.

memory.qmd.sessions.enabled.label: QMD Session Indexing
memory.qmd.sessions.enabled.help: Indexes session transcripts into QMD so recall can include prior conversation content (experimental, default: false). Enable only when transcript memory is required and you accept larger index churn.

memory.qmd.sessions.exportDir.label: QMD Session Export Directory
memory.qmd.sessions.exportDir.help: Overrides where sanitized session exports are written before QMD indexing. Use this when default state storage is constrained or when exports must land on a managed volume.

memory.qmd.sessions.retentionDays.label: QMD Session Retention (days)
memory.qmd.sessions.retentionDays.help: Defines how long exported session files are kept before automatic pruning, in days (default: unlimited). Set a finite value for storage hygiene or compliance retention policies.

memory.qmd.update.interval.label: QMD Update Interval
memory.qmd.update.interval.help: Sets how often QMD refreshes indexes from source content (duration string, default: 5m). Shorter intervals improve freshness but increase background CPU and I/O.

memory.qmd.update.debounceMs.label: QMD Update Debounce (ms)
memory.qmd.update.debounceMs.help: Sets the minimum delay between consecutive QMD refresh attempts in milliseconds (default: 15000). Increase this if frequent file changes cause update thrash or unnecessary background load.

memory.qmd.update.onBoot.label: QMD Update on Startup
memory.qmd.update.onBoot.help: Runs an initial QMD update once during gateway startup (default: true). Keep enabled so recall starts from a fresh baseline; disable only when startup speed is more important than immediate freshness.

memory.qmd.update.waitForBootSync.label: QMD Wait for Boot Sync
memory.qmd.update.waitForBootSync.help: Blocks startup completion until the initial boot-time QMD sync finishes (default: false). Enable when you need fully up-to-date recall before serving traffic, and keep off for faster boot.

memory.qmd.update.embedInterval.label: QMD Embed Interval
